newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Durch overnight rates continue Thursday's rise.
newsitem.headline: Durch overnight rates continue Thursday's rise.

text.p: Most Dutch money market rates seemed unaffected by the bond market's slide on Friday, remaining stable in disorderly pre-weekend trade.
Only call money was significantly up, quoting 2.81 to 2.94, while most deals were done at 2.87, some 20 basis points higher than on Thursday.
"I don't think the rise (in call money) is due to a tight allocation, although some players may have subscribed for a too small amount and may now be pushing the call up," one dealer said.
He said the main part of the rise was probably due to the pre-weekend effect, referring to the usual rise in overnight guilders ahead of the weekend.

This morning, the central bank allocated 7.455 billion guilders to the money market under a seven-day special advances pact at an unchanged rate of 2.50 percent. The pact replaced an eight-day facility of 6.47 billion guilders which expired today.
The flurry on the surrounding bond markets did not seem to have a significant effect on Dutch money market rates.
"Clearly, a lot of money is going out of bonds, especially from investment funds, but I don't see it flowing into the money market at the moment," one dealer said.
As bond deals are settled three working days after they are done, he said he did not expect a big impact from this pullout of bonds on the money market before next week.
"If it is going towards the money market at all," he said.
One-year deposits were quoted 3.20/28, up from 3.16/24 yesterday.
Trade was concentrated on overnight money and one-month deposits, dealers said.
The guilder held steady against the mark, quoting 112.17 per 100 marks, as it did on Thursday.
